bibl.title: Letter from Azel Ames to James Carroll, October 3, 1904

div1.p: Ames objects to the inadequate recognition given to Carroll, Lazear, and Agramonte for their yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Azel Ames to James Carroll, October 3, 1904
div1.opener:
C2
B1
Personal
24 Yale Avenue.
Wakefield. Mass
Oct. 3. 1904.
Dr. Jas. Carroll.
Asst. Surgeon U.S. Army
My dear Doctor,
div1.p:
You probably know
of me, as I of you, by the
work in which each has had a
hand. Like you, I started
out in the Spanish War, (with
purely philanthropic intent)
as an Actg. Asst. Surgeon and
though promoted for services
rendered to Major Brigade
Surgeon. I do not forget that
the chief of the medical
work of that brief war & espe-
cially that which reflected
chief honor upon the profes-
sion of medicine, the country
and the Army was performed
by Actg. Asst. Surgeons. -- and
I don't propose to permit others
to forget it either.

I am just in receipt of a
communication from Gen De-
Witte. Being of the Walter
Reed Memorial Assn. which
is the cause of this letter to
you. I honor Major Reed and
value his work as highly as
any man on earth and will
go as far as any in the effort
to perpetuate his name and
the recognition of what he did,
always provided -- it is not
at the expense of others and
in derogation of what they did.

I recognize that he was the
master-mind and organizer
in your work in Cuba and
that he is, no doubt, entitled
to the greatest credit and
should and will have it,

But, I do not agree that
to give him his rightful need
of recognition and honor, it is ne-
cessary, just, or right to ignore,
minimize or put out of sight the
essential, heroic, devoted, and
equally valuable work, in its de-
gree, which you and Lazear and
Agramonte did, -- and in and
for which Lazear gave his
life and you offered yours,

I will not consent to pass
unchallenged this exclusive
effort to do honor to Reed
who was not the originator of
the mosquito theory -- though he
and you and the others were its
demonstrators-, and have yourself
Lazear and Agramonte treated
as of no account in the matter.
Let us have these honors fairly
rendered and fairly divided

The Medical Staff of the Reg-
ular Army, or, to put it more
correctly, the War Dept and the
Surgeon Generals Office, have
always endeavored to “hog”, and
to arrogate to themselves, all
credit for any achievements won
by anyone in connection with
the Service, though most of them
have been won by volunteers or
Actg. Asst Surgeons.

The jealousy of Sternberg,
Hoff. Borden and others lest
some credit for something cred-
itable shall go to someone
not a “Coburger” or of the
“sacred circle”, has caused
a deal of injustice and
meanness which is sure to
come out, and I mean it shall
Borden did good work. but is ambitious

I have, as I have said,
-- but need not say, -- no wish
to distract in the last, from
the high honor and recogni-
tion which should be given
Reed, -- on the contrary I would
make it more, rather than
less, than others, and am not
afraid of giving him too much
for what he really did, but
I will not do it at the ex-
pense of the dead Lazear,
or at that of yourself or Ag-
ramonte. -- for that is to
dishonor him. There is no
honor so empty as that which
is filched from another and
when it is filched from the
dead it becomes damning
dishonor!

I am sure Reed, if living,
would not permit such in-
justice, Dead, no true friend
of his will suffer-, much
less -- seek, its perpetration

I propose to stand up and
fight. -- if I stand alone -- for
just recognition in your great
work, to all engaged therein
and I mean to stand, for the
rest of my life, as the advocate
of highest honors, not to deeds
of destructive value human brave but to
deeds of equal courage and
devotion to the saving of life,
to the blessing instead of the
destruction of mankind. I wish
you would send me. (in strict
confidence if you like) all the
facts and whatever has been printed
as to the work of your commission
at Quemados, I wish to be fully
informed. I will take no step with-
out consulting you but I mean to be armed to demand
that honors shall/go where they belong.
